I found this video doing some casual research on how the bird tail is used and found it quite interesting.  It seems that the tail is an elevator and rudder with the bird's ability to twist the angle of the tail.  Until now, though, I never noticed a bird could narrow its tail for speed and then flare (fan out) the tail feathers to increase drag and maneuverability.  Fascinating creatures!

I vehemently disagree about the flicker fusion rate. 25-30 FPS video is displayed twice for each frame; i.e. 50 or 60 Hz. The flicker from this is blatantly obvious, as is the low framerate (despite the motion blur of film). Flicker on a CRT with low persistance phosphors is easily seen into the 85 Hz range by most people. 60 Hz with low persistence phosphors, which is not what was used on CRT TVs but on computer monitors capable of higher refresh rates, is brainmeltingly bad.

Destin, I have a question, and I can't find a video of yours that has covered this. Scenario: You are driving along a road and you decide to pass a car. As you approach, you happen to glance at the wheels spinning, but for a split second you can see individual spokes before it becomes a blurred wheel again. Why is that? I have been trying to find research of my own on this and have not been able to find it, but I seem to have MAYBE understood it from watching this video. Is it because we are able to sense that particular image we just took, like a camera, for a finite amount of time? This is a very good question. It seems there could be no intermediate forms between being capable of flight and not. But paleontologists have posited many possible intermediate forms. Bird-like dinosaurs could have first used flapping as a way of assisting a climb up a tree to escape a predator. Gliding may have come before powered flight. Raptors(as in "Velociraptor") may have used their wings/arms to leap higher and farther while hunting smaller prey, and landed talons-first.

He is right about the human eye, your 120-144Hz monitor just makes moving images look more fluid, you are still watching at 18hz.
In the real world, after "18fps" (because what you see is light not frames per second) your eye will add some kind of motion blur to make what you see more fluid, that's way different to the frames being displayed on your monitor at 120 or 144hz.
That rainbow cat is awesome!

I think Destin's information about the perception of flickering light is accurate, but you are correct too. An image that changes very quickly will allow you to perceive higher frame rates. Imagine a car that moves 2 inches across your screen between frames. If doubled your frame rate, the car's motion would look smoother. Think of it another way - if your monitor is displaying a still picture, can you tell the difference between 5hz and 100hz?
Ostriches seem to do alright using their wings as brakes or control, so even though they seem to have evolved the other way, wings have non-flight utility.
I would say it's just a case of defining the difference between detecting a flicker and being able to identify 2 alternate frames - the 2nd of which being what he meant.

Love your video's, but do some more research on human detection of flicker rate. It is a common misconception that we can only see about 30 frames per second, and while at first the un-trained eye might agree, those of us with 120hz or 144hz monitors for gaming know this is not true. The specific number varies on the person, but is much closer to 100hz and above. Please thumbs up so all of us can learn a bit more about this :)
such a beautiful bird...

I heard some debate (I forget where, it's been a while) that birds could have evolved from a certain species of fish. If you think about it, their  hollow bones and aerodynamic shape would be useful for a creature underwater. The wings would have been useful for swimming, too. There are also signs of this today in the 'flying fish,' if you've ever heard of them. They're basically normal fish that have extended fins for when they jump out of the water and 'fly' to catch bugs.

Gliding is a thing. and it's pretty useful for getting from place to place at a low energy cost. It's not a stretch of imagination how that can evolve to full blown flight. Look at the ancient bird relatives, they were more like gliding lizard things than they were full fledged flyers..

The hoods aren't as tight as they look and even if you tried it'd be hard to choke them because the cartilage rings in their trachea are complete circles, unlike humans. Birds also stress out very easily, which makes rehabilitating injured birds very difficult. Considering all the strange people around that day for the filming, the hood was needed to keep the bird focused. Otherwise it would be so distracted by its surroundings it wouldn't fly to the target to be able to get these great shots.

Correct me if I am wrong, since time and vision and two completely different separate things.
Eagles manage to see a second of images divided in 100 captions and see edges and sharp borders.
While us Humans to see a fluid second of images would require us 18 captions only.
Fast moving objects then blur because our eyes does not perceive so many captions for us to be able to sharply see it moving, whereas an eagle would. For example, try looking at your hand while moving it very fast.
Basically.

Another way to put it is that if a bird watches a video with a normal frame rate of 24-25 frames (pictures) per second, it looks like a slideshow. They see, say, 100 fps, and we see 15-25 fps. So, what we see as a normal video of 25 fps, they see it like we see 6 fps. So, a fast slideshow, sure, but it doesn't look like a video. Another way to put it is that if you move your hand very fast in front of your eyes, it gets blurry, but the birds would still see it as "normal".

Great video Destin! What you're pointing out with the UV light recognition also is true to shooting pigeons or any other bird. Pigeons have a white line across their wings and body which radiates UV so if you set up a Dead pigeon on a moving trap, the pigeons flying overhead see the UV on the dead bird and sees the movement. As they are naturally inquisitive, they then come down to see what's going on... BANG... Works a charm, hope this interested you :)

Flicker still appears at much higher frames rates than 15hz. that's why in theaters where movies are shown at 24fps, each frame is projected twice, that means 48 flashes a second. In  cinema early days films were projected at 16 to 18 fps ( each frame projected twice means 32 to 36 flashes/sec) that is the vey low limit where flickering is noticable. Thats also why on TV 30 fps (25fps in Europe) are shown interlaced that means the image is refreshed 50 to 60 times a second to avoid flickering.

I studied ornithology in college. The instructor "demonstrated" how birds fly by making some sort of "figure eight" pattern in the sweeping motions of their wings. @jonyhamastix Think about it like this:  when you're driving on the highway at around 65 mph, and you look at the road right in front of your car, it looks like a blur, because the road moves so far in between your eyes' "frames."  Birds would be able to see details of close-up objects when moving at high speeds while flying due to their higher flicker fusion rate.  The object doesn't move as far in between "frames."

@PIllusion007 
For pigment, yes.  For light, no.  The three basic colors for light are Red, Green, and Blue.
